I can't believe it... a QUALITY RPGMaker game?!

About the game:

OH! RPG! is an intriguing role-playing game created by RosePortal Games, a developer you might know from their previous game, Epic Quest of the 4 Crystals. Built with RPGMaker MV, it is a tribute to both the software and the genre as a whole, but also an enjoyable game in its own right. It stands out by telling a story of a world where the heroes were unable to defeat the evil that threatened it, and so humanity is forced to prepare for their inevitable demise. Interestingly, the playable cast consists not of the heroes themselves, but instead various characters that would simply be NPCs in other games, such as a jester or an old lady. The heroes interact with these characters in different ways throughout the story, sometimes receiving help from them and other times providing assistance as they attend to their own desires. While the game is not particularly long, the world is developed so that you still get the feeling of a place that has been adventured through, with already-looted chests and allusions to unseen events. All of this results in a surprisingly compelling setting that, though very recognizable to anyone who has played a classic RPG before, still manages to feel novel.

Gameplay:
The gameplay of it stays true to the nature of JRPGs.

Pros:

~ Huge levels to explore.
~ The game is made from RPG Maker MV.
~ Story so far is interesting.
~ Lots of hero skills to vanquish evil with.
~ Tons of weapons to find and use.
~ Battle system is good.
~ Attack animations are cool.
~ Tons of monsters to fight and level up.
~ Sidequest can be easily to get if you travel everywhere.
~ The music is improved here, and there's a great combination of guitar and a more traditional sound for the genre.


Cons:

~ Fighting can get repetitive.
~ Story gets slow at parts.
~ It can take a long time if you don't know what you are doing.

-I haven't played a lot, but i can recommend you this game, if you like the genre!-

[Review Copy Provided]

OH! RPG! is, unsurprisingly, an RPGMaker game. At first glance you would think that it is just one of the 138 RPGMaker games that have joined (or plagued?) the Steam store. But, my child, before we jump to conclusions please read this full review. Or simply  jump to the bottom for the TL;DR if you have ADHD.

Story-We all struggle with our patience in RPGMakers. It's only natural. But OH! RPG! managed to bring a refreshing story which isn't just your typical OH! BORING CLICHED RPGMAKER! The premise of the story is that a group of heroes have failed their mission to save the world, however, you -the side character- have taken it upon yourself to face the aftermath of these heroes' mistakes with them. It's an intriguing idea and quite effective- though it can drag on at points. Each character has their own interesting personalities with their own humour. I must say, when I saw one of the negative reviews that said:

Originally posted by Kistulot:Not Recommended
5.4 hrs on record
Posted: 21 January
The game uses too many blatant time wasting minigame mechanics, and its humor doesn't work, unless you like heroes being jerks as a great joke. I was willing to try to enjoy it and see it through until I got to the Nun's arc, and encountered this: http://i.imgur.com/VGJTjNX.png

This is not humor.
I seriously starting laughing my head off. Funniest joke in the game just got funnier. But overrall, interesting story with a great idea.

Gameplay-You control your character through well designed levels and try gathering resources to help you as you encounter the many enemies lurking around. As you are not controlling the heroes you are much weaker when it comes to boss fights. You need to carefully manage your resources and target enemy weaknesses to be most effective. Only problem with this is that the combat can become slightly repetitive occassionally as you will find yourself dying a lot. There also seem to be some bugs to do with crashing but the developer seems to be working on it and accepting feedback. The save system seems to be a bit broken as well.

Graphics-The pixel graphics are very good, backgrounds look just as nice.

HUD-When you open the game up there is a variety if options icluding control configuration.

Music and sounds-Great soundtrack that was fits the game well, decent sound effects.

Summary
Pros
✔ Original idea
✔ Great story
✔ Interesting characters
✔ Good humour
✔ Interesting gameplay
✔ Good graphics
✔ Variety of options
✔ Great soundtrack

Cons
✘ Story can drag on at points
✘ Combat can be repetitive
✘ Some bugs
✘ Save system seems to be a bit broken

Conclusion
OH! RPG! is a breath of fresh air in the overcrowded RPGMaker collection. Is has some minor flaws but they are quickly passable because of the amount of great things the game does. If are wanting to pick up an RPGMaker game, this one should be up there on your list.

reviewText:
Oh! RPG! is an RPG maker game of upper quality , which is rather rare in this ocean of RPG Maker games available. The music is really good. The graphics - or rather the choice of tile sets used - are very cute, colorful, crisp and clean.

Where the game truly shines is in the gameplay - or more precisely WHO you play. You don't play the heroes - who are mainly selfish brats anyway - but the background-second-roles-NPCs you generally meet in these types of games: for example in the first chapter you play a goblin; in the third one an old lady! Telling you more about these characters would be huge spoilers but just know that even though they're very limited and one dimensional, they're very endearing with their reckless bravery. All want to stand and fight for different reasons. I'm amazed a small RPG maker game managed to make those tiny characters so interesting, funny and attaching.

About the combats, those characters are indeed weak but fear not, you'll be able to call the 'heroes' for help - if they do indulge to respond lol! For this part you'll have to juggle with a very limited number of loot (healing potions included) and a limited number of heroes calls. At first the learning curve is a bit stiff but you'll be satisfied as your NPC characters will slowly grow stronger and be able to fight on their own. You'll also find equipement and upgrades but be careful as the upgrades parts are very limited. So what I first thought out to be a casual RPG game turned out to be very interesting, rather challenging and kept me on the edge of my seat. i.e. nothing more satifying than managing to take out 3 huge rats all on your own when you play a tiny weak goblin!

The story is divided in 8 chapters, 3 (IIRC) of them are only a small narrative sequence. The 5 playable chapters are quite long, requiring an hour each. The story have all the usual classic dramatic clichés from J-RPGs: Evil Emperor taking over the world, world which is 'dying' and slowly collapsing etc. But it's sprinkled with a ton of humor: funny item descriptions, heroes with an attitude, funny dialogues, small details everywhere... I really liked it! It's a perfect balance for a second degree narration: a spoof of RPGs with a challenging gameplay.

You can replay any chapters whenever you want to make better scores to unlock a couple of stuff - like heroes to cast during combats. Some chapters features mazes so you'll have to be patient and cautious. There's a zone with puzzles. There's also some achievements to make and secrets to find and you'll have to replay the previous chapters to unlock all the secrets..  So the gameplay never gets dull. And you can play with your XBox Controller (very important point to me). Be warned that the game gets very hard toward the end but this makes winning the game even sweeter! My Playthrough lasted 9 hours and I still have a couple of achievements to make that should add a couple of hours (at least), so the game length is very decent.

The game quickly grows on you and it's hard to put down - you want to see what comes next. Really, this game is a small gem... Don't miss it!

OH! RPG! tells the story of a group of heroes after failing their quest to save the world, travelling through the game world back to their home places to experience the end of the world with their relatives and loved ones. You as the player will, however, not play as the heroes themselves, as their story has already been written. Instead, you take the role of various NPCs they encounter, which have their own business in mind. With each chapter you will take control over a different person in that game world. The story after the failure of the heroes is pretty much what you'd expect, without big surprises or twists. It gets close to being an actually sad tale, but it ultimately failed to draw me in at the end. I was pretty much left there with a huge question mark over my head before realizing that's all what I'd get.

With that in mind, you will never play, level up and equip a character more than for maybe an hour before losing your progress and switching on the next one. It feels very dissatisfying that you only level up, gear up and learn those skills just to face a boss monster 30 minutes later and after defeating it, to start all over on a new character, in a new area, with a new story, and a new boss monster.

The graphics are pleasing, even though at some parts of the game my frame rate dropped to around 5 for a few seconds. The sprites are very well done, the skill effects are cool and the soundtrack is particulary great. It fully manages to create the atmosphere it needs for certain areas, like a dark, demon-posessed forest.

I have mixed feelings about the gameplay. For one, the combat mechanics are well done. You can upgrade your equipment and your potions to make them stronger. The RPG elements and character progression are there and feel very real, but this is the crucial thing I dislike about OH! RPG!: They aren't. Nothing you do is persistent. Potions and upgrade materials are very limited and are heavily required to face the chapters' various bosses, thus creating a very linear experience in a game of a genre that's actually known for player's freedom. There are no shops in the game, so you gotta stick to what you find in treasure chests.
The essence of an RPG is to become stronger, to develop the character in a certain way, but these mechanics have no real meaning in OH! RPG!. Ironic for a game whose name consists for more than 50% of the term RPG".

RPG!, the idea is to imagine what would happen if the heroes fought in the final battle and lost.  What happens then?  Here is where the NPCs come in to help the heroes and face the aftermath. reviewText:
OH!RPG! is a puzzle RPG in a similar vein to that of 30 Second Hero, but instead of time management it is more about resource management and exploiting weaknesses.

Each scenario has you in control of a unique, often weak character and it's your goal to get them through various enemy and boss encounters to reach their goal. Since they are not the heroes, you will need to use their special attacks and carefully balance how much MP and many recovery items you use over the course of the scenario so that you are capable of defeating the final boss.

It's a fun little game but it does verge on frustrating when you have to lean on unreliable mechanics (e.g. evasion, confusion, critical attacks...) and every boss has the potential to just one shot you out of the blue. The dialogue also loves to break the 4th wall which gets a little grating but the story is a fun little spin on the formula and I quite liked the ending.

reviewText:
Oh! RPG! is the new game of RosePortal Games. It's an 16-bit JRPG  where you're going to play as NPC and help heroes along the way to return at home after their ludicrous failure against a big demon.

This is a new twist of the story and you can play it from another perspective.

The main character is easy to control using five keys and mouse, or you could you only use mouse to perform all actions.

Graphics are color full and have well detailed Japanese cartoon style.

There are a variety of well performed musics and sounds are quite normal.

There is a lot of humor in dialogs, and all characters have their personality well defined.

Combat system has multiple options but is a little different. You're alone and you fight using your own powers and potions but you can also invoke the power of the heroes and their special skills. They arrive in a number of turns so you must plan their appearance and survive until then. The hero will be different for each battle depending on where they are in the story.

During the game you can collect material to upgrade the power/efficiency of your weapons, armor and potions. The game has little crafting menu to customize them as you want. All objects are their statistics detailed.

At the first moment the game introduces you in all the aspects using some hints and tips.

The map is not complex but i miss the little map of the area in the corner of the screen that appeared in its previous game.

I'm playing the first chapter as a little goblin, but the game has seven more and as the developers say each chapter has a
different atmosphere, game play and a new character to play with.

The game has achievements and trading cards.

It's a good choice if you like Japanese style role games.

PD: I was provided with a key by the developer to beta-test the game before release

reviewText:
OH! RPG! is a turn-based RPG made by developer RosePortal Games in RPG Maker MV.

The game starts right where a typical RPG game would end, at the epic battle featuring the
heroes versus the final boss. The player is then presented with a very interesting premise; this time the heroes are defeated and forced to run away knowing that the world will end because of their failure.

In this game the player does not play as the heroes themselves, but as the various NPC that they encounter throughout their shameful journey back home. The game is composed of eight chapters, each of them starred by a different character and with a different style.

Scenarios are colourful, varied and well designed, and the music adapts well to the situations presented.

As for the gameplay, the game is basically a standard old-school RPG game, with turn-based battles, weapons and armor the player can find and equip and usable items such as healing potions.

Even though the heroes will not always be present in the party,  providing they are nearby the controllable character can use their skills in battle... The player must keep in mind, however, that these special attacks take some turns to activate, and that using them too much will result in a lower User rank at the end of the chapter.

The game presents an interesting crafting system that allows for items and equipment to be greatly upgraded directly through the menu.

All in all, the game is fun and entertaining, and I believe it to be worth playing. I would recommend it to fans of old-school RPG games and to anyone that finds the game's premise intriguing.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I received a key from the developer in order to test/leave feedback on this game. I have not been compelled to leave positive feedback and have judged this game by my own standards.


OH! RPG! is a game that starts where other games would usually end- with the heroic party being defeated by the final boss. This is usually where you'd enjoy a Bad End with credits or at least reload and try again- but these heroes just have to live with it and accept the help of an unlikely source... but you're the unlikely source and the heroes are mechanically just sporadic 'summons' who might be around to help you help them out- or once you switch perspectives, they're just around while you're doing something important to your new character. You get to play as what would normally be NPCs, to sum it up, in an RPG universe where the world is pretty much coming to an end. Surprisingly, it's less dour than that sounds like it should be.
I write this review having completed the first section of the game and having dug into the second section. Take note that even on Easy Mode, I find that I can't just sleepwalk my way through the game. It's not impossible-hard, but I would say that you probably should have some sort of background in turn-based RPGs because the game doesn't hand-hold much past the first section. As far as I can tell, due to the episodic nature of the sections of the game, you can't and won't be level-grinding and you have to deal with whatever items you can find, as well as deciding what items to improve with the crafting items you find along the way.
Overall, I would recommend the game to anyone who likes turn-based RPGs and is interested by the quirk of the game. Even though the sections seem like they will be fairly short and will probably continue to be- I liked playing the game from the differing perspectives and had at least some small interest even in the first character I played as.

Dear RosePortal and Aldorlea,

I don't mind that your game is using RPGMaker. It's overused, but it's in the tag list, so I know what I get. The engine doesn't matter when the game is made with love.

I don't mind that you re-use all of the default assets in RPGMaker. Maybe you have a good story to tell and you don't have the budget for a graphic artist, unlike fellow RPGMaker game The Amber Throne. That's okay. Making games is hard and sometimes not very rewarding, so you want to limit your losses whenever you can.

I don't mind too much when you don't do the extra effort of making the game work fine on modern computers and monitors, like, a bigger window. There are scripts for that, but I suppose your laziness isn't a mortal sin.

But I do mind when in addition to these, you start taking the banner used for RPGMaker MV as the basis for your own logo and splash screen... Including its ugly font, for crying out loud!
If it's not part of the assets licensed away to you, then it's called theft. I don't need to know the rest. All I see is that you release game after game, never taking time to give them a proper identity. Is this one a good game? I don't know, would you rather watch Iron Man or a cheap rip-off like Metal Man?

I don't buy from thieves. But I felt a need to represent gamers with a conscience and post this review, so I got a key through a cheap trade and made my money back through card farming.

I only support people who recognize their errors and make amends to those they wronged. You can still do it later I suppose, but you won't mean it, so either way you win yourself a negative review.

reviewText:
A very nice, short, interesting RPG experience.

The pixel art and music are top-notch and are very, very well done. The core gameplay is cool, and the concept is something you probably haven't seen before.  It's rather short for an RPG ( I beat it in 6 hours) however it doesn't overstay it's welcome and presents a decent challenge.

As long as you aren't looking for a traditional open-world RPG experience, you really can't go wrong with this game, at it's current price. I paid about $1.50 for it but I would have easily paid $5.
